fields.description:
"Renaming users is not supported" (the current error message) implies that renaming users is never supported in Crowd.

"Renaming users is not supported for <long name of type of directory> directories" would be ideal, but "Renaming users is only supported for  internal and remote Crowd directories" is also acceptable.
fields.summary: Renaming LDAP users via Crowd web app should give a clearer error message

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce

# Create an application and enable aliases
# Create a user in an internal directory
# Go to the list of applications the user has access to. Set up an alias for the user
# Rename the user
# Return to the list of applications the user has access to

h2. Expected outcome

The alias is preserved.

h2. Actual outcome

The alias is lost.
fields.summary: Application aliases are lost when user is renamed
Unable to add LDAP group into a local group when using Delegated Authentication Directory

fields.description:
== Steps to reproduce ==

# Setup scheduled backups. Wait until at least a scheduled backup has been made.
# Go to Administration > Backup
# Crowd correctly reports that there are some backup files, between date X and date Y
# Submit the first form (the Scheduled Backup form).

== Expected outcome ==

The report is visible after submitting the form.

== Actual outcome ==

The report disappears from the screen after submitting the form.
fields.summary: Report of existing scheduled backup files disappears after form submission

fields.description:
= Steps to reproduce =

# Setup Crowd, make sure you skip the mail server configuration
# Login into the Crowd console, go to Administration > Mail Templates

The screen shows the following error (see screenshot):

{noformat}
Failed to find entity of type [com.atlassian.crowd.model.property.Property] with identifier [mailserver.message.template] 
{noformat}
fields.summary: Error message in Administration > Mail Template if mail server configuration is skipped during setup

fields.description: This issue existed before, but it is now more noticeable because these fields can be initially empty if the mail server configuration has been skipped during the setup process.
fields.summary: 'Notification Email Address' and 'From Email Address' in Administration > Mail Configuration should be marked as required fields

fields.description: Password encoders are now shown in an essentially random order (due to CWD-3543?). They should be in alphabetical order and {{ATLASSIAN-SECURITY}} should be the default without relying on ordering.
fields.summary: Default password encoder should be ATLASSIAN-SECURITY

fields.description: Go to 'Administration' and click 'Update' for general options. The left list of sections vanishes. (This is likely to be due to CWD-3469.)
fields.summary: Sidebar vanishes after form submission

fields.description:
PersistenceTestHelper uses HsqldbDataTypeFactory for non-hsqldb db tests, which results in massive log spam by DbUnit when we run e.g. Oracle DAO tests (or any other database DAO tests).

Since there are proper implementations of org.dbunit.dataset.datatype.IDataTypeFactory for each of these databases, we should use those instead.

Perhaps we can set up a configuration property in the crowd-test-runner/crowd-dao-database-test/src/test/resources/*-jdbc.test.properties which specifies the fully qualified class name of the correct IDataTypeFactory for each database?
fields.summary: PersistenceTestHelper uses HsqldbDataTypeFactory for non-hsqldb db tests

fields.description:
We need a lightweight plugins system so AUI can be available during startup.

This work is currently required as part of the ADG work in Crowd.
fields.summary: Provide a lightweight plugin system for Crowd startup

fields.description: CacheManagerEhcache behaves like a manager of caches and also like a singleton cache. Remove this latter behaviour to improve identification of what's being cached and to simplify the API to prepare for caching changes.
fields.summary: Remove DEFAULT_CACHE from CacheManagerEhcache

fields.description:
[MariaDB|https://mariadb.org/] aims to be a replacement for MySQL. [MariaDB versus MySQL - Compatibility|https://mariadb.com/kb/en/mariadb-vs-mysql-compatibility/] states:

bq. MariaDB is a binary drop in replacement for MySQL

We still need to consider support and documentation, especially if there's customer confusion about compatibility.
fields.summary: Support for MariaDB

fields.description:
Some directories, notably LDAP connectors, do not support user renames. An attempt to rename a user produces an error.

For these directories, the option to rename a user should be disabled, possibly with an explanation.
fields.summary: Disable the field to rename a user if the directory does not support user renames

fields.description: This would be a very simple change and would make it easier to get started with a new project: http://mvnvm.org/
fields.summary: Consider adding a mvnvm.properties file to the project

fields.description: Currently "[About the Crowd Administration Console|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/About+the+Crowd+Administration+Console]" documentation does not provide any link to "[Granting Crowd Administration Rights to a User|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Granting+Crowd+Administration+Rights+to+a+User] which could lead to confusion  to users in regards on how allow users or groups to access Crowd administrators console.
fields.summary: Add "Granting Crowd Administrators" link to "About the Crowd Administration Console" documentation

fields.description:
Authentication with delegated LDAP does not work in case:

0. JIRA has Directory with setting: Delegated LDAP Authentication with "Copy user on login" enabled. 
1. User is created in LDAP
2. The same user is created in JIRA (for Delegated LDAP directory)
3. Created user tries to log in

Login is unsuccessful with the following error: {code} com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidUserException: User externalId cannot be changed {code}

It seems that while creating user in Jira it gets an externalID parameter from InternalDirectory. Later on when we log in user is found in LDAP with different ExternalID. ExternalID cannot be overwritten so login fails.
fields.summary: Authentication with delegated LDAP does not work in common case
Delete the CrowdHttpTokenHelperImpl singleton and related singletons.

fields.description: Build UI to allow users to be renamed in Crowd. Allow for the fact that renaming is only supported by some directories.
fields.summary: Add UI to rename a user in Crowd

fields.description:
Every Atlassian application has different scripts formats and workflow. We should have a common format guidelines to make them consistent between applications.

This will bring us the following wins:
* Sysadmins of Atlassian products will be able to configure any product in the same way, reducing the learning curve.
* Some pages in the documentation (and also the KB space) would be valid for all products, making them easier to maintain.

I personally like the way the files are formatted in JIRA (and Bamboo) but we should agree in a common format.
fields.summary: Get consistent start, stop, configuration and installation scripts across Atlassian products

fields.description:
# Log in to openidserver at /openidserver/
# Browse to /openidserver/

Observed: decorated login page with menu options such as My OpenID, Profiles, etc on the left and the login page in the center

Expected: the My OpenID page

Found during https://shipit.atlassian.net/browse/SHPXXIV-32
fields.summary: OpenID server shows login page if user is logged in

fields.description:
# Navigate to the edit profiles page of the crowd id server
# Add a new profile
# View the profile
# Click the "Make Default" link

Observed: CSRF token missing message

Expected: currently viewed profile becomes the default profile & the current default profile is no longer marked as default

Found during https://shipit.atlassian.net/browse/SHPXXIV-32
fields.summary: Can't change default profile for a user in crowdid server

fields.description:
It would be really interesting provide EAP releases of Crowd, as already available to other Atlassian products. 
Since it's a popular authentication solution to making use within JIRA and Confluence, we could collect users impressions about the features and code changes, helping us to improve our released software.
fields.summary: Provide EAP releases.

fields.description: Support Oracle 12c as Crowd backend database
fields.summary: Support for Oracle 12c

fields.summary: Multiple REST calls at the same time has cwd_token race condition.
DirectoryManager.addAllUsersToGroup() does not differentiate between existing memberships and failures

fields.description:
Occasionally you need to add many users to a group or a single user to many groups. Unfortunately, in both cases, there is no way of performing these operations in the REST api. Instead you need to add each user individually to each and every group that you want them to belong to: resulting in many api calls. 

There should be bulk operations for these tasks in the REST API's.
fields.summary: Make bulk user and group operations avaliable via the REST api.

fields.description:
https://jdog.atlassian.net/browse/JDEV-24470

eg
* Start with User A and B in LDAP
* Synchronise
* Delete A and rename B to A in LDAP
* Login as A
fields.summary: Full LDAP login cannot handle a chained rename

fields.description:
We're currently using postgresql:postgresql:9.0-801.jdbc4 but org.postgresql:postgresql:9.2-1003-jdbc4 is the latest available, and the postgres site recommends using the latest.

Note the different groupid in the new version, and that the suffix on the version is now "-jdbc4" rather than ".jdbc4".
fields.summary: Upgrade postgresql driver to 9.2-1003-jdbc4

fields.description: Guava broke binary compatibility for CacheBuilder between 10 and 11. To allow Crowd to be used with both versions, rewrite {{DirectoryLockManager}} without reference to Guava.
fields.summary: Avoid use of Guava CacheBuilder in crowd-core

fields.description: Generating UUID overwrites external id for delegated LDAP with option copy users on login. This means that rename for delegated ldap is impossible - external id in internal directory do not match the one in LDAP.
fields.summary: Generating UUID overwrites external id for delegated LDAP

fields.description: In {{CrowdHttpAuthenticatorImpl}}, the response from *GET /config/cookie* method could be cached to prevent multiple calls for the same cookie, especially in high traffic installations.
fields.summary: Allow for caching when retrieving cookie configurations (GET /config/cookie method)

fields.description: In incremental synchronization we need to delete users using external Id. This is required to support rename user corner cases. In case when external id attribute is not defined we should fall back to deleting by name.
fields.summary: Change the way users are removed during incremental synch
Add a "Copy User on First Login" flag in the Delegated Directory Configuration

fields.description: Crowd uses Guava 11.0.2 which is quite a few versions behind. We should upgrade to the latest one.
fields.summary: Upgrade Guava to 18.0

fields.description: Creating reusable user and group matchers for tests allows us to simplify a lot of existing tests, and makes writing future tests easier.
fields.summary: Create User and Group matchers for tests

fields.description: When we authenticate user using Delegated LDAP and we rename user in JIRA, external Id for this user is lost.
fields.summary: External Id is lost when user is renamed in JIRA

fields.description: We have reverted the order (now its : first delete than add / update) for full synchronization in order to rename users. We should apply this change also to incremental synchronization.
fields.summary: Reverse order of operation add / delete for incremental synchronization

fields.description:
We have found that while some consumers of the PasswordEncoderFactory can bootstrap the 'system' encoders, not all can.

We need to improve the constructors of the PasswordEncoderFactory so it can be a better citizen.
fields.summary: Improve the PasswordEncoderFactory so it can be preloaded with 'system' encoders

fields.description: {{DirectoryManager.addAllUsersToGroup}} will aggregate failure and return any users that could not be added in a {{BulkAddResult}}. It should not declare {{UserNotFoundException}}, as that case will be returned in the results rather than raising an exceptin.
fields.summary: DirectoryManager.addAllUsersToGroup should not declare UserNotFoundException

fields.description:
h1. Symptoms

Crowd does not pick user renames from upstream LDAP directories for new directories.

h1. Steps to reproduce

# Create a new cached Connector or Delegating Directory in Crowd
# Check the cwd_directory_attribute table in the database

h1. Expected result

The newly created directory should have a value for the "ldap.external.id" attribute in that table, and as a consequence, externalIds should be picked and synchronised in the cwd_user table.

h1. Actual outcome

The newly created directory does not have a ldap.external.id attribute in that table. As a consequence, externalIds from the upstream LDAP server are not synchronised and saved in the cache. And therefore, Crowd is unable to detect upstream user renames.
fields.summary: Crowd does not set the ldap.external.id attribute for new connectors/delegating directories

fields.description:
There used to be a filter that set the request encoding in crowd, but it got removed a while ago (see CWD-2649) because it used to set the content-type as well.

The request encoding is now set by webworks, i.e. fairly low down the filter chain. That means that if any filter higher up the chain (such as OAuthFilter) tries to access the request parameters, they will be parsed using the default encoding (ISO-8859-1) instead of UTF-8.
fields.summary: Explicitly set the request encoding to UTF-8 in a filter

fields.description:
Currently the Crowd documentation regarding the MS SQL database setting did not mentioned about the collation setting : 
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/MS+SQL+Server
As we did for MySQL: 
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/MySQL

If the collation is not case sensitive, it could cause installation failure or other problem.
fields.summary: The collation setting needs to be clarified in the MS SQL setting page

fields.description: As part of our Applinks 4.0 upgrade we will need to put in SAL 2.10.
fields.summary: Upgrade Crowd to 2.10 of SAL

fields.description: From the application point of view, the creation/removal/change of an alias is perceived as a user rename. Once Crowd-to-Crowd incremental sync supports user renames, there is no need to invalidate the incremental sync anymore on alias events, they can be rewritten as application-specific rename events.
fields.summary: Recast alias change events as user renames for incremental Crowd-to-Crowd sync

fields.description: Crowd server should make UserRenameEvents available to applications that know how to handle them. For applications that don't know how to handle them (old Crowd clients), then UserRenameEvents should invalidate the event-based sync to cause a fallback to a full sync.
fields.summary: Pass through UserRenameEvents to applications that can handle them for event-based sync

fields.description: Detection of user renames from LDAP relies on LDAP servers making available a unique, immutable identifier ("external ID"). In order to detect user renames from remote Crowd servers, an identifier of similar characteristics must be available.
fields.summary: Create a unique, immutable identifier for users exported by a Crowd server

fields.description: Crowd's build date shown in the footer is currently {{dd-MM-yyyy}}.  For ease of reading and comparison, ISO-style {{yyyy-MM-dd}} would be better.
fields.summary: Use yyyy-mm-dd order for build date in BuildUtils

fields.description:
When the 'Copy user on auth' option is enabled, the active/inactive status of the remote user should be copied to the delegating directory.

Note that may imply that the user cannot authenticate, because it has been disabled in the LDAP directory.
fields.summary: Synchronise remote user active/inactive status on auth for Delegating Directories

fields.description:
Would it be possible to allow for multiple domains in the SSO configuration?
We have to similar domains, and we would like to be able to use SSO between the 2 domains.  We currently have the SSO domain set up to be picsauditing.com, but we would also like to include picsorganizer.com.
fields.summary: Allow multiple domains for SSO in Crowd

fields.description:
It'd be helpful for auditing purposes if Crowd displayed the account creation date or last updated date for users on its ['User Browser' interface|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Using+the+User+Browser] or even via [REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources#CrowdRESTResources-UserResource].

h3. Workaround
At this point, it's only possible to retrieve such information on Crowd's database. There are timestamps for both operations in the {{created_date}} and {{updated_date}} columns of the {{cwd_user}} table.
fields.summary: Include user created_date and updated_date information to User Interface

fields.description: The {{TokenDAO}} abstraction requires a {{search}} method which isn't ideal for some possible implementations. Pull the other methods up into a new interface and, where possible, use it.
fields.summary: Provide a simpler SPI for session token storage

fields.description:
To avoid the need for applications using Crowd as a user management service (e.g. FishEye/Crucible), having to copy all users in a crowd directory to their local user directory, please provide a new remote API in crowd which lets an application test if a user is able to authenticate against the Application in Crowd.

FishEye/Crucible are currently calling:
{code}
authenticateSSOUserWithoutValidatingPassword
{code}
to test whether or not a user has access to FishEye as defined in Crowd.
The side effect of calling this method is that an SSO session is created in Crowd. This is not ideal, as described by the user in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-4573 .

A new method would allow an application to determine the list of users who have access to FishEye without fisheye creating SSO sessions in Crowd.


History: 
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-1348
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-4573
fields.summary: Provide a new API to allow a client to test whether or not a user can authenticate against an Application in Crowd without creating a SSO session in Crowd

fields.description: Currently selecting a subset of users to sync from LDAP requires constructing LDAP query strings by hand. We should provide a better UI experience around this, so that it's harder to set up broken filters.
fields.summary: Provide UI for filtering users to synchronise

fields.description:
a new Crowd sync with AD fails in 2.6.5 with a org.hibernate.TransactionException: Transaction not successfully started error. 

Performing a new Crowd sync with AD works fine in 2.6.4.
fields.summary: AD sync fails

fields.description: Publish an event called UserRenamedEvent when user is renamed during directory synchronization or when user logs in and rename is triggered by the change found in directory.
fields.summary: Publish UserRenamedEvent when user is renamed in LDAP
For Internal and Caching directories, when searching for memberships you should be able to apply a search restriction to the result

fields.description:
There's [a bug|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/PLUG-927] in the web resource plugin which is causing a few IE bugs due to incorrect web resource load order.

We need to either update to plugins 3.x, or backport the fix to a 2.14.0 (or 2.15.0) release if that's going to be too problematic.

fields.description:
Like already discussed in our support request (CWDSUP-7916) we see possible security issues with the current implementation of SSO in Crowd.

The Crowd REST API allows any application that can create session tokens to create this tokens without password (POST to /session?validate-password=false). The consequence in a SSO environment is, that any application authentication can be used to compromise all other applications.  The application doesn't need to know neither the token nor the password for retrieve the user token. As far as I know that option is mainly for the "remember me" functionality. The parameter "validate-password=false" cannot be disabled so we need to filter all requests with this parameter in our reverse proxy to block this feature.

The real solution in our point of view is a login system where the web-application doesn't need to know the credentials, because the authentication provider is the only one which creates the tokens.
See the linked [figure|http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E21764_01/webcenter.1111/e12405/wcadm_security_sso.htm#CEGGJFIB] for details.
fields.summary: Modernizing the Single Sign-on Process Flow
Don't re-set 'directory' for RemoveDirectory

fields.description:
The message shown to users who request a new password is both non-conditional (it does not validate and report whether-or-not the username entered actually exists) and can be inaccurate (it can report that a password reset email will be sent when that is not true). The message that is shown is ALWAYS the following:

"An email is on it's way! It contains a unique random URL. Click the link in the email message or copy it to your browser address bar. The link leads to a page where you can choose your new password."

Steps to reproduce:

1) Access Crowd console
2) Click the "Can't access your account" button
3) Choose either option
4) Enter a non-existing username/e-mail, or even leave the username field totally blank.

Note that the first issue (message is non-conditional) has been raised in another issue report - https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2457 and has been closed with the following explanation from Atlassian:

"This is by design, in order to prevent using this page for checking whether the user exists in the database."

We don't want this issue to duplicate that (closed) one, but are curious why this is the case when other Atlassian products do not follow this same design rule. For example, the Confluence forgot password interface (which may even be using Crowd as a directory) does explicitly inform the user if the submitted username was not found. Can someone clarify why this is?

Even if that message will remain non-conditional, there still seems to be a notable UX issue remaining here. The message that is displayed can be very misleading as it always informs users that an email was sent even though this is not always true. If there are no plans to make the message conditional, it would certainly make sense to at least change the wording of the generic message. Perhaps something like the following would be more appropriate:

"Thank you. If we find an account matching the username you have entered you will receive an email with further instructions and a reset password link. The link will lead to a page where you can choose your new password."
fields.summary: Password reset messages are misleading and not conditional (UX issues)

fields.description:
Authorization bypass 
(Attacker can alter another user details)

Steps - 
1) Create two test users A & B
1) Login as USER A to https://openid.atlassian.com
2) Click profiles and view the source to capture the profileID of user A
for ex - you can find below similar code in profile html view source to capture profileID

<input type="button" class="button" value="Delete" onclick="location.href ='/secure/profile/editprofiles!doDelete.action?profileID=15826981&atl_token=d664b23ab7fb8664ce7690b579ff6379eec9712e'"/>

3) Now logout from user A and login as user B
4) Go to profiles
5) Enable tamper data (mozilla plugin) which is required to tamper the form
6) Change some details on profile (such as nick name, full name, email ID etc). and when clicking save button tamper the form using tamper data tool and Change user B profileid value to user A profileID. (profile id is submitted as part of form parameter value)
7) Now logout from user B and login as User A. You will be surprised to see that the data changed from userB is reflected here in User A.
fields.summary: Authorization bypass

fields.description:
{{CrowdHttpAuthenticatorImpl.isAuthenticated}} should only check the session after {{sessionValidationInterval}}. However, it makes an unconditional check that the request has a Crowd token cookie present. The check ignores the fix in CWD-2326 to use the remotely-configured cookie name, which means it doesn't cause a performance problem. However, in the case of a token name mismatch, it could cause a user to wrongly be reported as unauthenticated.

Move the check after the validation time check and use {{getCookieTokenKey()}}.
fields.summary: CrowdHttpAuthenticatorImpl doesn't always use the remotely configured cookie name

fields.description:
Currently, it is not possible to log into Crowd if the user exists in the second directory and the same user is disabled in the first directory 

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up 2 directories in Crowd
# Create one user in each directory with the same username
# Disable the user in the first directory (the first order in the list)
# Log into Crowd and you will see  "Invalid Login" error as well as this error in the log:
{code}Couldn't instantiate class. com.atlassian.crowd.integration.exception.InactiveAccountException{code}

When the order of the directory is changed, the user can log into Crowd again.

The improvement would be: if the user is disabled in the first directory, Crowd must check if the same username exists in the second directory (or other directories in the list) and if it exists and it authenticates successfully, Crowd must allow the user to login.
fields.summary: Allow the same user in the second directory to log into Crowd when the user is disabled in the first directory

fields.description:
We have discovered a vulnerability in WebWork 2, which is a part of the Struts web framework. 

In specific circumstances, attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use these frameworks. 

In case of Crowd, the attacker needs to be able to access Crowd Web interface. A valid user account is not is required to exploit this vulnerability.

Customers should be advised that this effects all previously released versions of standalone Crowd server, except Crowd 
2.3.9, 2.4.10, 2.5.5, 2.6.4, or later. Standalone Crowd is not used in OnDemand.

For more information on this issue, please see the security advisory [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+Security+Advisory+2013-07-16].
fields.summary: Webwork 2 code injection vulnerability

fields.description:
When a user attempts to login through an account that is managed remotely (LDAP or Crowd), JIRA / emb crowd should synchronise the user's details (username, display name, email and group memberships).
You only need to add new group memberships for groups that have already been synchronised - it is OK to ignore others.
The group synchronisation should happen before we check for permission to log in - the user may have recently been added or removed from the required group.
See https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-26882 for some background
fields.summary: As an admin, I want external user details synchronised during login

fields.description:
RequestCacheThreadLocal holds a per-request "cache" that is used, in particular, by Crowd's implementation of WebResourceIntegration (and in turn, by WebResourceManager and SoyTemplateRenderer).

This cache is initialized and cleaned-up in RequestCacheThreadLocalFilter. This filter is mapped to a number of patterns, including /plugins/servlet/*. However, it is mapped only for the REQUEST dispatcher.

Our problem in our plugin is when using the QUnit plugin: it uses URL rewriting so you can access it using /qunit, which is not covered by the mapping. It eventually ends up forwarding the request to /plugin/servlet/something but since the mapping does not apply to the FORWARD dispatcher, the filter is never applied.

Other problem: RequestCacheThreadLocal defines an initial value. However:
* it is also initialized in the filter, which is redundant
* the clean-up code sets the thread local value to null, instead of calling remove()
fields.summary: RequestCacheThreadLocalFilter is not applied to /qunit resources
